Award.AwardTitle: Asymptotic Problems of Partial Differential Equations with Random Coefficients: Homogenization and Beyond
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research is devoted to the analysis of systems with parameters that contain uncertainties and vary on multiple scales, and the goal is to understand their effects on the dynamics of the systems. Examples of such systems are ubiquitous in nature: climate and weather developments, oceanography, and seismology, just to name a few. Similarly, multiscale processes with built-in uncertainty are common in many large-scale societal phenomena, from stock market behavior to propagation of information through social media. The mathematical subject is partial differential equations (PDE) with random and highly oscillatory coefficients, and the project is aimed at deriving effective models that incorporate the impacts from the randomness and the separation of scales. The project is expected to result in connections to multi-scale algorithms, inverse problems, imaging, and uncertainty quantification, as well as to have applications in subjects such as climate prediction, geophysics, and materials science.

The project involves three investigations, with a focus on questions related to stochastic homogenization, wave in random media and stochastic PDE: (i) study the quantitative aspects, including convergence rates and statistical fluctuations, of stochastic homogenization and macroscopic models of wave propagation in random media; (ii) analyze the effects of different correlation properties of the randomness on both qualitative and quantitative aspects; and (iii) investigate the transition from deterministic to stochastic models, and study the convergence to stochastic PDE beyond the homogenization regime.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we studied various prototype partial differential equations (PDE) that model physical processes such as heat conduction, front propagation, species invision, surface growth etc. Due to the internal disorders or the inprecision of the measurements, the parameters associated with the equations are modeled as random processes. To understand the propagation of the randomness through the complicated dynamics given by the PDE is crucial in numerous applications. Roughly speaking, what we have achieved in this project is a better understanding, in some specific models, of the propagation of the randomnesses through multiple temporospatial scales. 

The research supported by the award has led to the solutions of several open problems in PDE, probability and mathematical physics, including (i) results on high order correctors in stochastic homogenization, (ii) results on the statistical properties of two dimensional parabolic Anderson model, (iii) a proof of the Edwards-Wilkinson limit for the random heat equation in high dimensions. We have also developed new approaches leading to (i) another proof of the Wong-Zakai theorem for stochastic heat equation, (ii) a path integral approach to the random Schrodinger equation. Some results have brought new perspectives and insights to uncertainty quantification, PDE based Bayesian inverse problem, non-equilibrium statistical mechanics, etc. I list two examples below.

(i) The work with Ivan Corwin considered a model of species invasion in heterogeneous envionrments. Around the propagation front of the species, we observe a non-trivial non-Gaussian statistics associated with the population density, which comes from the heterogeneity of the environment and the fact that we look at the front rather than the bulk. The statistics can be described through a stochastic partial differential equation, the so-called Kardar-Parisi-Zhang equation which sits at the center of 1+1 dimensional random growth models. 

(ii) The work with Li-Cheng Tsai studied an approximation of a random heat equation. The result shows that depending on the time scales, we have either a determinstic behavior of the solution where the random effects average out or a stochastic behavior where small fluctuations accumulate for a sufficiently large amount of time to become visible. We also illustrates a typical mechanism under which a transition, with respect to different time scales, from normal to abnormal statistics takes place. 

 

The award has supported the PI to attend conferences and workshops, and the PI has designed and taught undergraduate/graduate courses, and organized working groups at Stanford and Carnegie Mellon University. The PI also advised undergraduate students and served as a mentor for the CMU summer undergraduate research program.
